user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_DeleteAllObjects:
```c
void OS_DeleteAllObjects(void)
{
    uint32 ObjectCount;
    uint32 TryCount;

    /*
     * Note - this is done in a loop because some objects depend on other objects
     * and you will not be able to delete the object until the ref count becomes zero.
     */
    TryCount = 0;
    while (true)
    {
        ObjectCount = 0;
        ++TryCount;

        /* Delete timers and tasks first, as they could be actively using other object types  */
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        /* Then try to delete all other remaining objects of any type */
        OS_ForEachObject(OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        if (ObjectCount == 0 || TryCount > 4)
        {
            break;
        }
        OS_TaskDelay(5);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_DeleteAllObjects:
void OS_ForEachObjectOfType(osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t creator_id, OS_ArgCallback_t callback_ptr,
                            void *callback_arg)
{
    OS_object_iter_t    iter;
    OS_creator_filter_t filter;

    filter.creator_id    = creator_id;
    filter.user_callback = callback_ptr;
    filter.user_arg      = callback_arg;

    if (OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ForEachFilterCreator, &filter, idtype, &iter) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
        {
            OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(&iter, OS_ForEachDoCallback);
        }

        OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);
    }
}
...
void OS_ForEachObject(osal_id_t creator_id, OS_ArgCallback_t callback_ptr, void *callback_arg)
{
    osal_objtype_t idtype;

    for (idtype = 0; idtype < OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER; ++idtype)
    {
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(idtype, creator_id, callback_ptr, callback_arg);
    }
}
...
void OS_CleanUpObject(osal_id_t object_id, void *arg)
{
    uint32 *ObjectCount;

    ObjectCount = (uint32 *)arg;
    ++(*ObjectCount);
    switch (OS_IdentifyObject(object_id))
    {
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK:
            OS_TaskDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_QUEUE:
            OS_QueueDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_BINSEM:
            OS_BinSemDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_COUNTSEM:
            OS_CountSemDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MUTEX:
            OS_MutSemDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MODULE:
            OS_ModuleUnload(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE:
            OS_TimeBaseDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB:
            OS_TimerDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM:
            OS_close(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_DIR:
            OS_DirectoryClose(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR:
            OS_CondVarDelete(object_id);
            break;
        default:
            break;
    }
}
...
int32 OS_TaskDelay(uint32 millisecond)
{
    /* just call the implementation */
    return OS_TaskDelay_Impl(millisecond);
}
...
int32 OS_TaskDelay_Impl(uint32 millisecond)
{
    struct timespec sleep_end;
    int             status;

    clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &sleep_end);
    sleep_end.tv_sec += millisecond / 1000;
    sleep_end.tv_nsec += 1000000 * (millisecond % 1000);

    if (sleep_end.tv_nsec >= 1000000000)
    {
        sleep_end.tv_nsec -= 1000000000;
        ++sleep_end.tv_sec;
    }

    do
    {
        status = clock_nanosleep(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, TIMER_ABSTIME, &sleep_end, NULL);
    } while (status == EINTR);

    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        return OS_SUCCESS;
    }
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB 0x09
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE 0x08
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK 0x01
...
#define OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I have flagged fragments where code execution may be statically or practically unreachable (or where iteration bounds vs. the numeric object-type constants could make certain paths never executed):
- Calls that pass explicit object-type constants (TIMECB/TIMEBASE/TASK) and the subsequent generic OS_ForEachObject call — these rely on the iterator accepting those type values.
- The OS_ForEachObject loop header using OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER as the loop bound — mismatch between this bound and the explicit object-type numeric constants can make iterations (and therefore callback invocations) never occur.
- The iterator-init conditional and its inner while loop in OS_ForEachObjectOfType — if OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit fails for some idtype the inner body becomes unreachable for that idtype.
- The while(true) loop in OS_DeleteAllObjects together with its break condition (TryCount/ObjectCount) — included because the loop control could hide unreachable code paths or create a logic that never exits in some configurations.
- The clock_nanosleep do/while loop — included because repeated EINTR can prevent progressing to subsequent code in some environments.
- The large switch on OS_IdentifyObject — included because, combined with potential iterator/type-range issues, some case branches may never be reached.

Why other fragments were NOT flagged: small wrappers and straightforward return/alias definitions (for example the trivial OS_TaskDelay wrapper that just calls OS_TaskDelay_Impl, the simple filter struct setup in OS_ForEachObjectOfType, and the macro alias OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY) do not by themselves introduce statically unreachable code and so were not listed. The flagged fragments are those where there is a realistic risk (by mismatched numeric type values or iterator/init conditions) that code paths can never be executed and therefore should be investigated for compliance with MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.
